choices.text: Above the margin of a rib
Below the margin of a rib
Lateral to the margin of rib

questions.text: When inserting a chest tube, intercostal vessels and nerves are avoided by placing the tube immediately:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The intercostal vein, artery, and nerve (VAN) run in the costal groove along the inferior border of each rib-making it dangerous to insert a tube below the rib margin (Option B ruled out)
  • Placing the chest tube above the rib margin avoids these neurovascular structures (Option A is correct)
  • Lateral and middle of the rib are non-standard and do not ensure safety from VAN structures (Options C and D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Always insert chest tubes just above the upper margin of the rib to avoid the VAN triad
  • Intercostal neurovascular bundle runs along the inferior rib margin
  • Proper anatomical knowledge prevents iatrogenic injury

questions.text: A needle inserted into the 9th intercostal space along the midaxillary line would enter which space?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The costodiaphragmatic recess is the lowest part of the pleural cavity, formed where costal pleura meets diaphragmatic pleura
  • At the midaxillary line, it extends between ribs 8 to 10, making the 9th intercostal space ideal for accessing this recess.
  • Cardiac notch is located on the left lung anteriorly, not at the 9th intercostal space (Option A ruled out)
  • Costomediastinal recess lies anteriorly near the sternum, not midaxillary (Option C ruled out)
  • Cupola is the dome of the pleura above the first rib, not near the 9th space (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Costodiaphragmatic recess is accessed at 9th intercostal space in midaxillary line for thoracocentesis
  • Location of pleural recesses varies with thoracic level and line (MCL, MAL, paravertebral)
  • Insertion should be above rib margin to avoid VAN structures

questions.text: The ductus arteriosus sometimes remains open after birth requiring surgical closure. When placing a clamp on the ductus, care must be taken to avoid injury to what important structure immediately dorsal to it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops around the aortic arch just posterior to the ductus arteriosus (or ligamentum arteriosum) and ascends in the tracheoesophageal groove (Option D is correct)
  • Accessory hemiazygos vein is located more posteriorly in the thorax and is not directly related to the ductus arteriosus (Option A ruled out)
  • Left internal thoracic artery is anterior, running down the inner thoracic wall, not dorsal to the ductus (Option B ruled out)
  • Left phrenic nerve runs more anteriorly over the pericardium and is not immediately dorsal to the ductus (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve lies posterior to ductus arteriosus and is vulnerable during PDA surgery
  • Injury may cause hoarseness or breathing difficulties due to laryngeal muscle paralysis
  • Essential to identify and preserve this nerve during thoracic surgeries

questions.text: During a surgical procedure in the vicinity of the descending aorta, a surgeon accidentally cuts the first aortic intercostal artery. Which of the following structures might be deprived of its main source of blood supply?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The right bronchus typically receives blood from a single right bronchial artery, which may branch from:
    • A left bronchial artery
    • The right 3rd posterior intercostal artery
    • Or the first aortic intercostal artery
  • If the first aortic intercostal artery is cut, the right bronchus may lose its main arterial supply.
  • The first posterior intercostal space is supplied by the highest intercostal artery from the costocervical trunk, not the aorta (Option A ruled out)
  • The first anterior intercostal space is supplied by the internal thoracic artery (Option B ruled out)
  • The left bronchus has a dual supply from two bronchial arteries directly from the descending aorta (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Right bronchus often has a single artery which can arise from variable sources
  • Cutting the first aortic intercostal artery can compromise right bronchial blood flow
  • First intercostal spaces have alternate arterial sources and are not at risk

questions.text: Which of the following nerves would be most vulnerable to irritation when the tracheobronchial lymph nodes are enlarged due to a diseased situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tracheobronchial lymph nodes are located at the bifurcation of the trachea, near the arch of the aorta and left main bronchus
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, loops under the arch of the aorta near the tracheobronchial nodes and ascends toward the larynx-making it highly vulnerable to irritation from node enlargement (Option A is correct)
  • The right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the right subclavian artery, far from the tracheobronchial region (Option B ruled out)
  • Right and left phrenic nerves run laterally along the pericardium and are not in close proximity to these nodes (Options C and D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at risk with tracheobronchial lymphadenopathy
  • Enlarged nodes can cause hoarseness or vocal cord paralysis due to nerve compression
  • Anatomical course of nerves is crucial for understanding compression syndromes

questions.text: Referencing the provided anatomical diagram of the superior thoracic vasculature, what is the superior intercostal artery a direct branch of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The superior intercostal artery is correctly identified as a branch of the costocervical trunk, which is indicated by label A in the diagram. The costocervical trunk itself is a short, thick branch of the second part of the subclavian artery. The superior intercostal artery then descends anterior to the necks of the first two ribs, giving rise to the first two posterior intercostal arteries.

Explanation of Other Options:

B (Deep cervical artery) (Option B): Label B points to the deep cervical artery, which is another branch of the costocervical trunk, not the superior intercostal artery itself. The deep cervical artery ascends into the deep muscles of the neck.

C (Subclavian artery) (Option C): Label C points to the subclavian artery, which is the main artery in this region from which the costocervical trunk (and thus, indirectly, the superior intercostal artery) originates. However, the superior intercostal artery is a branch of the costocervical trunk, not a direct branch off the main subclavian artery in most anatomical descriptions.

D (Axillary artery) (Option D): Label D points to the axillary artery, which is the continuation of the subclavian artery after it passes the lateral border of the first rib. The superior intercostal artery arises well proximal to the axillary artery, from the subclavian artery's branches in the neck and superior thorax.

Key Takeaways:

  • The superior intercostal artery typically originates from the costocervical trunk.
  • It supplies the first two posterior intercostal spaces and is important for understanding the vascular anatomy of the superior thorax.

choices.text: They are present in all 1st to 12th intercostal spaces
The upper 9 intercostal spaces typically feature two anterior intercostal arteries each
They are direct branches of the external thoracic artery
They primarily anastomose with the highest intercostal artery.

questions.text: Regarding the anterior intercostal arteries, which of the following statements accurately describes their distribution within the intercostal spaces?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The statement that the upper 9 intercostal spaces have two anterior intercostal arteries each is correct. This dual arterial supply ensures robust vascularization. The lower intercostal spaces (10th and 11th) typically lack anterior intercostal arteries.
  • These two anterior intercostal arteries within each of the upper nine spaces originate from specific sources:
    • The arteries for the upper six intercostal spaces are direct branches of the internal thoracic artery.
    • The arteries for the 7th, 8th, and 9th intercostal spaces are typically branches of the musculophrenic artery, which is one of the two terminal branches of the internal thoracic artery.

Explanation of Other Options:

They are present in the 1st to 12th intercostal spaces (Option A):. As mentioned, the 10th and 11th intercostal spaces typically do not have anterior intercostal arteries, receiving their supply solely from the posterior intercostal arteries.

They are direct branches of the external thoracic artery (Option C): The anterior intercostal arteries are primarily branches of the internal thoracic artery and its terminal branch, the musculophrenic artery. There is no major vessel called the "external thoracic artery" that gives rise to these.

They primarily anastomose with the highest intercostal artery (Option D): The anterior intercostal arteries primarily anastomose with the posterior intercostal arteries (which are branches of the thoracic aorta or superior intercostal artery), forming a continuous vascular arcade within each intercostal space. The highest intercostal artery specifically supplies the first two posterior intercostal spaces.

Key Takeaways:

  • The distribution of anterior intercostal arteries is not uniform across all intercostal spaces.
  • The upper nine intercostal spaces receive a dual supply from two anterior intercostal arteries, which anastomose with their corresponding single posterior intercostal artery.
  • The anterior intercostal arteries are branches of the internal thoracic artery (for upper spaces) and its terminal branch, the musculophrenic artery (for lower anterior spaces).

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the emergency department following an anterior chest wall stab wound. A CT scan confirms arterial extravasation due to an injury to the internal thoracic artery. This injury would likely lead to a diminished blood supply through all of the following arteries, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The posterior intercostal arteries are not direct branches of the internal thoracic artery; therefore, an injury to the internal thoracic artery would not directly decrease blood supply through them.
  • The posterior intercostal arteries primarily originate from the thoracic aorta (for spaces 3-11) or the superior intercostal artery (for the first two spaces), making their blood supply independent of the internal thoracic artery's integrity.

Branches of the internal thoracic artery:

  • Terminal branches at the level of the 6th intercostal space:
  • Superior epigastric artery (Option A)
  • Musculophrenic artery(Option B)
  • Sternal branches to:
  • Transversus thoracis muscle
  • Periosteum of the posterior sternal surface
  • Sternal red bone marrow
  • Anterior intercostal arteries for the first 6 intercostal spaces.(Option C)
  • Perforating branches that pierce and supply pectoralis major and then become direct cutaneous vessels that supply the skin.

Key Takeaways:

  • The internal thoracic artery is a major artery of the anterior chest wall and gives rise to several crucial branches supplying the chest wall, diaphragm, and anterior abdominal wall.
  • Its main branches include the superior epigastric artery, musculophrenic artery, anterior intercostal arteries (for the upper spaces), and perforating branches.
  • The posterior intercostal arteries have a separate origin, primarily from the aorta, and are thus unaffected by internal thoracic artery injury.

choices.text: They supply the intercostal space up to the costo-chondral junction
First two pairs arise from branches of the thyrocervical trunk
Arteries on the right are longer than the corresponding ones on the left
There are 11 pairs of posterior intercostal arteries

questions.text: Rib notching was observed on chest X-ray, in a patient with Turner's syndrome due to enlargement of arteries in the inferior rib margin. Which of the following is incorrect about these arteries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The statement that the first two pairs of posterior intercostal arteries arise from branches of the thyrocervical trunk is incorrect.
  • The first two pairs of posterior intercostal arteries typically arise from the superior intercostal artery, which is a branch of the costocervical trunk (not the thyrocervical trunk).
  • Rib notching, often seen in conditions like coarctation of the aorta (which can be associated with Turner's syndrome), results from the enlargement and pulsation of these posterior intercostal arteries as they act as collateral pathways to bypass the aortic obstruction.

Explanation of Other Options:

They supply the intercostal space up to the costo-chondral junction (Option A): Posterior intercostal arteries run within the intercostal grooves and extend anteriorly to anastomose with the anterior intercostal arteries, thereby supplying the entire intercostal space up to the costo-chondral junction.

Arteries on the right are longer than the corresponding ones on the left (Option C): Most posterior intercostal arteries (from the 3rd to 11th) arise directly from the thoracic aorta. Since the thoracic aorta lies slightly to the left of the vertebral column, the posterior intercostal arteries for the right side must cross behind the vertebral bodies to reach the right intercostal spaces, making them longer than their left-sided counterparts.

There are 11 pairs of posterior intercostal arteries (Option D): There are 11 intercostal spaces, and each typically contains a pair of posterior intercostal arteries (one for each side), making a total of 11 pairs.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rib notching is a radiological sign caused by the erosion of the inferior margins of ribs due to enlarged, pulsating intercostal arteries acting as collateral circulation (e.g., in coarctation of the aorta).
  • The first two posterior intercostal arteries originate from the superior intercostal artery (a branch of the costocervical trunk).
  • The remaining posterior intercostal arteries (3rd-11th) arise directly from the thoracic aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a tributary of the left superior intercostal vein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The left superior intercostal vein typically drains the 2nd and 3rd posterior intercostal veins and sometimes the 4th
  • The left 1st posterior intercostal vein drains directly into the brachiocephalic vein, not into the left superior intercostal vein (Correct)
  • Left 2nd posterior intercostal vein contributes to the left superior intercostal vein (Option B ruled out)
  • Left 3rd posterior intercostal vein is a main tributary of the left superior intercostal vein (Option A ruled out)
  • Left 4th posterior intercostal vein may also join the left superior intercostal vein, although variably (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The 1st posterior intercostal vein drains directly into the brachiocephalic vein, not the superior intercostal vein
  • The left superior intercostal vein commonly receives the 2nd, 3rd, and sometimes 4th posterior intercostal veins
  • Knowledge of venous anatomy is key in interpreting thoracic imaging and collateral pathways

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into the structures marked A?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The structure marked A is the left brachiocephalic vein, which is formed by the union of the left subclavian vein and the left internal jugular vein
  • The left superior intercostal vein drains the 2nd and 3rd (sometimes 4th) left posterior intercostal veins and empties into the left brachiocephalic vein (Correct)
  • Hemiazygos vein drains into the azygos vein, not the brachiocephalic (Option A ruled out)
  • Superior thyroid veins drain into the internal jugular vein, not directly into the brachiocephalic vein (Option B ruled out)
  • Right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein, not the left brachiocephalic (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The left superior intercostal vein is a direct tributary of the left brachiocephalic vein
  • Understanding venous asymmetry is key in thoracic anatomy: left-side veins often drain into the brachiocephalic, right-side into the azygos
  • Brachiocephalic veins receive multiple tributaries including vertebral, internal thoracic, and inferior thyroid veins

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the marked area in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The marked area is the anterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib, located in front of the scalene tubercle
  • The subclavian vein runs through this anterior groove, passing anterior to the anterior scalene muscle

Explanation of other options:

  • Subclavian artery (Option B): This travels in the posterior groove, lying behind the scalene tubercle
  • 1st thoracic nerve (Option C): Not relevant; the brachial plexus lower trunk runs with the artery, not the vein
  • Internal thoracic artery (Option D): Descends along the inner surface of the thoracic wall, not in the groove of the first rib

Key Takeaways:

  • The first rib's scalene tubercle separates two grooves:
    • Anterior groove = subclavian vein
    • Posterior groove = subclavian artery & brachial plexus
  • The anterior scalene muscle inserts on the tubercle, creating this separation
  • Adjacent anatomy includes the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and subclavian artery in the posterior groove

References:

Gray's Anatomy for Students; Physiopedia; Radiopaedia

choices.text: Superior epigastric and inferior epigastric vein

questions.text: In a patient with inferior vena caval obstruction, which of the following collaterals do not help drain the blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In inferior vena cava (IVC) obstruction, collateral venous pathways compensate to maintain venous return to the heart
  • Superior and inferior epigastric veins anastomose to bypass IVC obstruction via the internal thoracic vein to SVC (Option A helps drainage)
  • Azygous and hemiazygous veins drain into the SVC and connect with lumbar veins, providing a posterior bypass (Option C helps drainage)
  • Vertebral venous plexus provides a valveless network, facilitating venous return from pelvis/lower limbs to SVC via vertebral system (Option D helps drainage)
  • Superficial epigastric vein drains into the femoral vein (tributary of IVC), and iliolumbar vein also drains into IVC, hence do not bypass the obstruction

Key Takeaways:

  • Collateral pathways help redirect blood from IVC to SVC
  • Important routes include: epigastric veins, azygous system, and vertebral plexus
  • Veins draining directly into IVC (like iliolumbar) are ineffective in bypassing an obstruction

questions.text: A pediatric case of foreign body obstruction came into OPD with symptoms of breathlessness. Where does the vein supplying the most likely site of obstruction drain into?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In pediatric foreign body aspiration, the right main bronchus is the most common site of obstruction due to its wider, shorter, and more vertical anatomy
  • The bronchial veins drain the lungs, and the right bronchial vein, which drains the right lung and right bronchus, empties into the azygous vein

Explanation of other options:

Right subclavian vein (Option A): Drains blood from the arm and part of thoracic wall, not from bronchial veins

Right brachiocephalic vein (Option B): Receives drainage from subclavian and jugular veins, not directly from the bronchial system

Accessory hemiazygous vein (Option D): Drains the left upper intercostals and some bronchial veins on the left side, not the right bronchus

Key Takeaways:

  • Right bronchus is the most common site for aspirated foreign bodies
  • Right bronchial vein drains into the azygous vein
  • Azygous system plays a critical role in thoracic venous drainage

questions.text: In the costal groove of which of the following ribs is the classic arrangement of vein-artery-nerve is not seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic neurovascular arrangement in the costal groove is Vein-Artery-Nerve (VAN) from superior to inferior, seen in typical ribs (ribs 3-9)
  • 1st rib is atypical-it is broad, short, and flat, with no well-defined costal groove, so VAN arrangement is absent
  • Subclavian vein and artery pass across its superior surface, separated by the scalene tubercle, not within a groove
  • In the first rib, the arrangement of structures seen medial to lateral are as follows: SVAN
  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein (intercostal)
  • Artery (superior intercostal)
  • Nerve (T1 nerve)

Explanation of other options:

2 (Option B): Considered atypical, but it has a shallow costal groove, and VAN may still follow typical arrangement

3 (Option C): A typical rib, follows standard VAN pattern

4 (Option D): Also a typical rib with classic neurovascular bundle arrangement

Key Takeaways:

  • 1st rib lacks a costal groove, so VAN arrangement is not seen
  • Typical ribs (3-9) have Vein-Artery-Nerve in the costal groove
  • Atypical ribs (1, 2, 10, 11, 12) may deviate from standard anatomy
